Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the weight of the black robe heavy on my shoulders, when the clerk rushed in with a thick file. “Emergency motion, Your Honor. They need a ruling within the hour.” I nodded, already feeling the familiar pressure of the bench—every word in that file could change someone’s life. I reached for the file, but my phone buzzed. It was a message from the synagogue office: a young couple wanted to speak with me about officiating their wedding next year. They were eager, hopeful, and I knew how much it meant to them to have their rabbi’s blessing from the very start. 

I stared at the file, then at my phone. The law demanded my immediate attention, but so did the couple’s faith in me. As a judge, I was expected to be impartial and thorough, never rushed. As a rabbi, I was expected to be present, compassionate, and available. My heart pounded as I weighed the urgency of justice against the sanctity of new beginnings, feeling the two worlds I cherished pulling me in opposite directions.
